job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: This is specific to the horticulture department at K-State. There are a few great faculty in the department that are kind and want the students to have a supported and positive experience.
cons: Generally, the department culture is very negative unless you work with a very small handful of faculty who take a genuine interest in their students and supporting them through their degree work. This is specific to Ph.D. work, they baby their M.S. students. If you aren't willing to sacrifice your health- mental, emotional, and physical, as well as show up grumpy and negative like them (even when you've only had three hours of sleep, too!!), then you really don't belong there because they will just assume you aren't working hard enough if you aren't as miserable as them. They are generally sarcastic, not happy people, and don't give care about their students unless you kiss-ass, click your heels, and... don't you DARE interrupt at the wrong time. There's a grad student lounge on the third floor- I was told this AFTER ONE YEAR OF BEING THERE! The office folks must have thought I was a weirdo for wanting to escape my office on occasion and eating my lunch in their lounge. Better than the third or fourth day where I hung out in the AGRICULTURE LOUNGE because I didn't know where a microwave was for me to heat my lunch. Oh, guess I wasn't working hard enough though since I was having a proper lunch- I probably shouldn't even have had time to microwave food and actually sit down to eat it while staring at a wall for 10 minutes.

pros: The job paid the bills. Good retirement plan if you can last through the waiting period to receive the match.  Good benefits. Great resume filler.  Companies like to see past employment with large organizations.
cons:
There were more people in positions who shouldn't be than I've ever seen in any other organization.  How can one effectively manage or oversee what one does not understand?  You don't have to be a subject matter expert in all areas but at least have a foundational understanding of job responsibilities. Group think drove me insane.  The "we've always done it this way" mentality coupled with no initiative to do more work than necessary was and probably still is costing the university a lot of money, which it did not have.  People performed processes without understanding why they were doing them which led to a lot of passing on of bad or non-compliant processes. Team work was a joke, there was a lack of ownership and authority between departments, and succession planning was non existent.

If you enjoy day to day chaos, no work life balance, silos, and lack of leadership, KSU is the place to be.

review_title: KSU physics department is the best place to gain experience and the worst place to make a living out of it
pros: KSU physics department is considered to be a great place for undergraduates to take apart in. There are a great opportunities for students to be upgraded and gain more experience from it. As an undergraduate, there are lots of potentials and opportunities for students to improve on their skills in teaching and grading other students. Note that it is rare the case in any other university to find an undergraduate instructor having a great responsibility of teaching other students the same age as they are.
cons: As great as the opportunity in teaching, there are some problems with that. The main problem for an undergraduate instructor is that there are no motivation for a good work at all. The main reason behind that is the management is insulated from the labs themselves. Another problem is that the lab instructor teaches a class for a professor that does not know anything about how the lab works (there are no commutation between labs and lectures) which leaves the professor outside of the lab scheme. Note that, when you work in a lab, your boss is different from your professor. One last Cons is the fact that the salary is too low compared to the amount of effort a lab instructor put through.

review_title: Great people with high support, high caring enviornment
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros:
At Kansas State where I was a GTA, program assistant, and writing tutor, I received plenty of support, caring advice, and help from superiors when I needed to vent, get advice, or get feedback. 

There's also literally an endless need for creative, flexible talent to start and run with their own projects-- management will reward you with praise and thanks (though not with any additional money).

Everyone is so positive and happy to be working there-- I have to say it's really a great working environment.
cons:
As in any university environment, but perhaps at K-State more than most, the salaries are very, very, incredibly low. We once did a fund raising "goodbye" card for an administrative assistant where everyone put in money for her. If you're working at a company that provides an adequate living salary, there's really no need to have a fundraiser for their living expenses. 

Most people made it work by being married or by receiving financial support from parents. From tenured professors to lowly GTAs, everyone made abysmal salaries, even though most employees work really long hours, are always connected to email, etc. 

Again, as with most universities, managers are not empowered to provide salary increases at all, so really our direct managers are not at fault-- they're getting paid poorly, too. But really, the "no power to change anything" culture reads somewhat as an excuse, and everyone needs to accept that it's up to them to change working conditions.

job_title: Food Service Worker in Manhattan, KS
pros: A VERY small number of people were kind and good people.
cons:
Management knew next to nothing about how to run a shift. I once had to instruct a upper level manager on several simple jobs. They left everything up to the lower level workers. I had a manager make racist and hypocritical comments about my hair and appearance. Another manager humiliated me in front of students and staff. 
Many of the works fought constantly and the morale was extraordinarily low. One time two workers got into a screaming match in front of students. Many of the employees would slack off or literally hide from their work leaving the rest of us to pick up the slack. I had to report one individual several times for disappearing for long stretches of time to get out of work. The management did nothing about this but a slap on the wrist and a poorly mediated meeting between this individual and me.
The people in the office were incredibly rude and racist as well. 
I witnessed several instances where whole groups of employees would use slurs when referring to trans or non-binary students, as well as minorities. 
The pay was far too low for the kind of work expected for this job. They also were not forthcoming in the interview about what sort of job was to be done and what shifts you would be working.

review_title: Good people and family friendly area
pros: The best part about working at KSU is the people. Most are very open and friendly and are often willing to lend you a hand if you need help or advise. The academic environment is fairly open and most people are not quiet as pretentious as those that can be found at some other big universities.  In addition the area is very family friendly with a fairly low crime rate.
cons: The location is probably the worst downside of working at KSU. The closest major airport is 130 miles away. Also the Manhattan area is undergoing a lot of redevelopment but it would be nice if there was a little more variety in the types of shops and restaurants that they are putting in.

review_title: Great place to work, but typically political infighting.
pros: Access to a great set of academic resources and greatly discounted tuition. Great benefits and further along the tech curve than public and private employers of comparable size.
cons:
Tuition discount doesn't apply to online learning fees, which fund a dysfunctional continuing education office. In many scenarios the University buys expensive software and develops custom alternatives to needed software that can be bought cheaply. 

Many positions are selectively advertised to qualify the opening for H1-B positions. No wage increases have been approved over the past three years. Worse, there's a general hiring freeze leaving many positions vacant while qualified employees jump for greener pastures. Meanwhile, rents are sky high.

review_title: Substandard land grant university with no clear vision for improvement
pros: Some departments have very nice facilities, financial stability, and enough conscientious faculty and staff to operate smoothly.  State employer, so there are better than average 403(b) options and vacation/sick days.
cons: The student population is definitely substandard, it is very difficult to recruit qualified staff to Manhattan, and there is a large tortuous bureaucracy invested in making itself relevant by routinely generating new arcane rules and regulations.  The health plan is awful because there in no useful coverage in Manhattan, KS.

pros: The pros of this job involve the facts that you are not overly swamped with work at all and are able to get a lot of homework done.
cons: The cons of this job is that the Managers do not actually pay attention to the students working for them, so they never see the things that need to be fixed. They also tend to disregard any suggestions that could improve the HelpDesk and are continuously stuck in their way of thinking, which does not evolve. This is bad because in a world of technology, a HelpDesk should be willing to adapt and evolve as well.

review_title: A rewarding work environment with a friendly culture
pros: The town is a great place to live, and the work environment is very friendly.  The degree of job stability is high, you are unlikely to be let go on a whim.
cons: Too remote from major cities so you have to be a small town sort of person to live there permanently.  This is a very big big downside if you are from a very large metropolitan area.

review_title: Graduate student life at Kansas State University
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: I had a great experience at my department as a graduate student. Great department head, major advisor and a multi-cultural research group! The International Students and Scholar Services (ISSS) department at K-State is a great resource for all problems and activities of international students. K-State offers several leadership and participation opportunities for graduate students. The funding situation and research endeavors are improving with the K-State 2025 plan. Great culture, students, staff and faculty are friendly and helpful!
cons: Career fairs and Career & Employment Services are more geared towards undergraduate placement. There are fewer opportunities for graduate students, especially international. The university must do something about this situation if they want to continue recruiting students from other countries.

review_title: Has been a very rewarding experience
pros: I have learned an amazing amount about controls, fabrication, and real world engineering. The mission of the lab is very cool and tip of the spear on the low flow turbocharger side of things.
cons: The high flow mission seems to be at the end of it's road. It will be interesting to see how the lab changes it's focus to something current in the natural gas industry. The leadership is pretty minimal as well. With one guy running both the operations and personnel, something has to be half done well.

review_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in the Division of Biology
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros:
- Teaching loads are manageable depending on the class.
- The people are great. 
- Graduate classes are generally well run and stimulating.
- Ample journal clubs and seminars covering a wide variety of fields. Some are better run than others. 
- All GTA's are supported in the Division of Biology with salary and a full tuition waiver.
cons:
- The department has taken steps to diversify the research interests of their faculty but is still heavily centered around hard ecology.
- There is a fair amount of between lab gossip.
- The department does not do an adequate job of preparing students for non-academic careers.

review_title: Great experience, decent students, acceptable staff
pros: Most students are excited to learn and try new things and proactively go out and seek new knowledge in their own with a you providing some exposure or direction.
cons:
Most of the colleagues in the college I worked in were married to each other. In a department of ~30 faculty there were around 6 or 8 married couples which made it a political nightmare to deal with unless you could get them on your side. 

However, they were relatively open to listening to MY suggestions...just not everyone's.

pros: You get to structure your schedule around your classes, and your managers/supervisors understand when you have tests or reviews. Some desk jobs allow you to study or do homework while at work. Overall general student employment is good for those looking for a few extra dollars and experience. However it would be hard to pay your way through college if you only worked through K-State.
cons: Minimum wage pay for most entry positions. Hours are limited to 30 a week. Not a lot of room to increase position ranks, as many supervisors are grad students.

review_title: Typical university setting, but with a little more
pros: Great town to live in, nice athletics programs, new president who is doing good things to grow the research function of the university, American has several flights a day to ORD and DFW.
cons: Town is far from anything -- Topeka is the closest, but is not a destination; will take anyone who graduates a Kansas high school; lots of politics (but that may be the case with any university)

review_title: Great quality education at a low cost.  Boring town.
pros: I received tuition reimbursement on top of a salary, interesting research work, and I collaborated with good professors.  If you're willing to put in the work for a few years as a graduate student, it seems to pay off quite well in the long run.  This is a great place to launch your career, particularly if you're an engineer or are interested in agriculture.
cons: Manhattan is a small, conservative town - it can be quite boring.  Weather gets a bit crazy.

review_title: Great environment for a working student.
pros: The managers are all faculty and will work around your class schedule.  They are very friendly and are willing to let you off work when there is an academic need (Extra Study, Speaking events, etc.)
cons: It was difficult to work as a part time employee here only because it's minimum wage and there was no pay increase in the 3 years I worked there.

review_title: Creative environment with room to find your own niche
job_title: Creative Services Department in Manhattan, KS
pros: You sometimes work odd hours, depending on the time of athletic events in the creative services department. There is plenty of opportunity though to be creative in your job and.
cons: Games are on weekends and hours are odd so they may not be for everyone, but overall a very fun work environment.

review_title: Good only if for less than 5 years
pros:
Working a research assistant while a graduate student can be managed easily with the on campus resources available to students
University offers events all year round
Employees are friendly
cons:
Limited parking 
It become boring after staying for about 4 years or more  (it is a college town)

pros: Seeks to do what every ambitious college should do, without being elitist. My peers are generous and helpful and continuous improvement is actively encouraged.
cons: As a state-funded institution, Kansas State University is subject to the same economic troubles the rest of Kansas is experiencing. This is partially counteracted by prudent budgeting and the strategic pursuit of outside funding; but the shock of repeated cuts is starting to hurt morale and curtail some of the school's plans for growth.

job_title: Student Quality Assurance in Manhattan, KS
pros:
Don't need a lot of experience
You really learn a lot
A great resume builder
There are also multiple ways to grow and move around if you want to do something different
cons: Not a whole lot of cons. Everyone is super nice and will want to get to know you. It can get boring sometimes when there is not a lot to do. Doesn't pay NEARLY as well as other developer positions.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: The city and the university are safe and quite .Manhattan is a great place to raise a family.People are smiley in and outside the university,many restaurants around the university,good university housing,the Hale library is a great place to study.
cons: The biggest Con for me is the Low GTA salaries in the department of biochemistry compared with neighboring biochemistry departments as in Nebraska or university of Kansas.indeed,there is difference in salaries between departments of the university.the parking spots in the university are limited.No public transportation.

review_title: Great People, Great Atmosphere, Great Research
pros:
-P.I.'s, Professors, and Ph.D. scholars all are focused on the mission of developing their research and aiding others whenever they can.
-Everyone has a positive nature about them; they all understand research is hard and so they try to help any way they can, whether it's people working in the labs, or the support staff.
cons: -Older buildings tend to have their share of issues, but they are easily worked around.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: The work load as a GRA/GTA has never been problematic to me. The college tries to make an effort to ensure that the GRA/GTAs are not overburdened.  The pay is pretty good too, plus partial tuition waivers.
cons: I earn a little more at my other job and the work can be a bit monotonous, but has not been problematic.

review_title: Invaluable problem solving and team work experience
pros:
•	Wrote macros in Excel using VBA to automate repetitive tasks such as monthly reports and career fair employer database.  Purified data from raw source; combined Excel with Access, PowerPoint and Word.

•	Designed interactive and user-friendly add-ins and custom menu commands for routine cleaning, organizing and formatting of data. Macros decreased human data processing time by 70% to 80%.
•	Administered macros to CSO (national software system automating career services for universities), and their clientele.
cons: I haven't had any experiences to suggest any cons.

pros: Employer works well with school schedule, benefits include room & board as well as a monthly stipend paid over 10 months, employees have summers off, and the job site is on-campus which makes for an easy commute.
cons: RA's are responsible for overseeing Hall policies are followed by peers. This can be frustrating because employees end up reporting violations made by friends and neighbors in the hall. While the job is great, this aspect can be a turn-off for people who don't like to get others "in trouble".

review_title: The environment at K-State is comfortable and accepting. Most people are friendly.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: My supervisors are friendly and willing to answer any questions I have. They care about the well being of students and will do anything to help.
cons: There is not much diversity at K-State. It is a conservative, predominantly Christian campus and many people hold strong beliefs regarding race and religion.

pros: They really work with students schedules. Fair pay for a low skilled job. Always at least 50 cents over minimum wage. A really good team to work with. The job was very close to where I lived. Overall I recommend working on campus if you are a student working retail or food service won't offer the flexibility needed to keep up with class
cons: Some really weird hours. One shift was 3am to 6am. But that was okay because I could do my homework at the front desk.

pros: If you are careful to intentionally choose where you would like to work to gain experience as a student, you can make valuable networking relationships and benefit from opportunities through that venue.
cons: You need to be REALLY good at networking to reach your full benefit. The culture of purple is very customer-service oriented and you need to be able to fit in with that.

review_title: Good place to work for a student
job_title: Economic Development Intern in Manhattan, KS
pros:
- This internship pays well compared to other jobs on campus
- The building is new and very well taken care of
- You get to be a part of the more business side of the university
cons:
- The location is not on central campus
- There isn't much of a development program built out for students yet

review_title: Great place to work as a student
pros: The hours are really flexible and the work with you to set your schedule every semester. If you are a good worker, they will work to keep you around even if you have to take a semester off.
cons: Sometimes there is a lot of sitting around. Some faculty can be difficult at times while others are really nice

pros: Great benefits working for the State of Kansas, flexible hours depending on job and supervisor.
cons: Very resistant to change. There have been no raises in years due to the budget situation. The only way to increase pay is to change jobs within the University. They do not practice employee retention unless it is a faculty member. The employee reviews that are used are ineffective. Poor performers are rarely reprimanded or fired which causes good employees to cover more than their share of work.

pros: Standard pros for a state university
cons: If you aren't a student, military, professor, married, or if you don't have children, you will not find much to do here. It's a small town and lots to do for those groups, but not much else if you fall outside of those groups. There's also the uncertainty of having a position at the end of the fiscal year due to state budget cuts. Last year's furlough fiasco left a bitter taste in several people's mouths.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: Great school, good atmosphere, lots of other graduate students, informative classes, lots of opportunities for scholarships, plenty of opportunity to travel to conferences, pays for part of health insurance
cons: Pay is minimal, rent is expensive in town (for the area), not enough classes for my interests, academic level is low in some areas

review_title: Great faculty and staff, outdated benefits and salary compensation
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: K-State has great resources for its graduate teaching assistants such as one-on-one mentorship, strong support system, and good teaching morale.
cons: Low salary, average health insurance plan, no mental healthcare coverage, slow to change university policies.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: Great school and very strong community support and involvement. Really nice if you prefer smaller town living. Topeka isn't very far away for more shopping opportunity and some of the buildings that have been remodeled are very nice. Very supportive staff and faculty at the school.
cons: Sometimes Manhattan feels a little too small and some of the buildings could use more modernization.

review_title: A transformational work environment with dedicated employees!
pros: K-State embraced me as an employee and I felt like I made hundreds of friends in months.  I can't get that everywhere so that is a huge positive!  Manhattan is also a great town to live in and has many family-friendly activities and events.
cons: At times, services seem to be decentralized but I do know that the University is working on improvements in this area.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: Climate and culture was very inviting, people are eager and available to help and collaborate, they find a way to get you what you need for projects, a lot of opportunities
cons: Administration needs to work on communicating and resolving issues more efficiently. Facilities and labs need to be updated.

review_title: Great place to work for students
pros: K-State offers a great place for students to earn some money while attending school. All of the employers understand the need for students to take time off for family/social needs or school projects. Decent pay for kids in school, especially if you are in somewhat more specialized positions.
cons: Senior management is often incompetent, more focused on politics and throwing around business buzzwords than anything else.

pros: Kansas State is full of wonderful, super-nice people, so working with them is awesome. I'm a student employee at the Rec, and we are constantly receiving applications from students wanting to work for us. It's a fun job and you meet tons of people. I've been working for the Rec for four years now, and I'm not going to quit until I graduate.
cons: It's paid by the state, so you aren't going to walk away super rich.

job_title: Teacher's Assistant in Overland Park, KS
pros:
-Helps you brush up on data structures/algorithms
-Hours are very flexible according to your classes
-Office hours are a great place to get extra homework done.
cons: -Personally I didn't mind this, but if you don't like helping people who are completely lost/ ignorant learners, then office hours and lab sessions can be a tad frustrating.

review_title: An opportunity to work at Kansas State is an opportunity to enhance your future.
pros: Raises are given on a yearly basis and most departments have opportunity for upward mobility.  If you hope to get a lot out of your job at K-State, your willingness to perform well and step into roles where you're needed determine how far you can go.
cons: Not everyone you will work with knows how to act as a professional, including those in higher positions.

review_title: Office Assistant - any miscellaneous office jobs that need to be done.
pros: Awesome culture - it's almost like "family" as the whole university is. Everyone shows their appreciation for you!
cons: There aren't really any drawbacks, I like my job! But as a student worker of course, you don't get any paid time off, which really shouldn't be expected.  But if I need to leave early for a school reason, they are very flexible - they know school comes first.

review_title: A peaceful place for studying and living
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: Living expenses like food, rent for house are much cheaper than most of cities in US. Most residents here are friendly. It's a safe place, you can leave you car windows open overnight without missing anything.
cons: Sometimes the weather is weird. There isn't any convinient public traffic, big shopping mall here. It is really a small country.

review_title: Fantastic crew of people to work with!
pros:
-VERY welcoming campus environment
-Great people to work with that share the same mission
-Low stress (dependent on your position)
-People truly try to make collaborative efforts
-BENEFITS
-Within walking distance to do many things you need
-Overall warm atmosphere
cons:
-Somewhat blurred lines when the university allows bibles to be handed out on campus
-CAN be tough to deal with people who won't/aren't capable of being directive
-There is SOME stinginess when it comes to salary for some positions

pros: Workable hours, not always the same task everyday, relaxed management and if working in the individuals field of study it add a good boot to resume
cons: Above minimal wage, however not extra high, but it does depend on the department the individual is working for, and some weeks no hours are available

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: Great campus. Good school overall. Offices are good on average. Friendly atmosphere all in all.
cons: Perhaps same as everywhere and varies from department to department and adviser to adviser. Nothing particular to school.

review_title: Was a great place where the students truly lead with conviction.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: The students are some of the most driven I have ever worked with. I have had the most amazing interactions with these students, whom have challenged me to be a better professional day in and day out.
cons: Having not went to Kansas State for my undergrad, I was definitely an outcast. Administration truly love "their own", and I felt suppressed at times because I was an outsider.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Manhattan, KS
pros: Great boss and students, supportive staff. Good work with autonomy and resources.
cons: The university administration struggles to deal with post-docs. There was some tick in the way summer pay was provided that meant payroll deductions doubled up in the spring, but the details kept changing from year to year so it was hard to plan around.

pros: Kansas State University is the best place to start your career as a researcher. Kansas State University values you and ur work.
cons: Kansas State University has some less funds may be due to its location or some thing. But few dept have very gud funds

pros: Good benefits, university was very good to work for.
cons: Where I was working suffered from a lack of leadership and promoting people based on who had been there the longest vs qualified. The department needed new leadership. I left because of the old boy network that was intrenched.

pros: For the most part, students, staff and faculty are very polite.  Manhattan is a nice sized college town with a wide variety of services (and they now even have a rudimentary public transportation system!). Overall, upper management is positive and supportive.
cons: Respect of work/Life balance can vary significantly by department. Some students are completely focused on grades and miss out on the main point of education: learning and developing a strong skill base.

pros:
Benefits include 22 vacation days and 14 sick days per year (they don't expire at the end of the year) and 12% employer 401K contribution. Health insurance is around $50 per pay check for the whole family and they give you an additional $2250 per year to cover your deductible.
Relaxed, non-pressured work environment 
Small college town, so no traffic
cons:
Less salary than an equivalent industry position 
Not much growth opportunity.

pros: The people are fantastic and the environment is full of energy. I love the feel of a college campus and the hours are not terrible.
cons: There are some days that get really hectic because of lots of people showing up and all of them not knowing what to do. There are also moments where the world seems to be falling apart because nothing works. It's typical of any job involving college students.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros:
This is a perfect place for doing research.
Manhattan,ks is a really nice town.
Kansas State University has a open mind for diversity students.
cons: For my opinion, the location is the only cons in my mind. It takes two hours to drive to the nearest city.

pros: It a fantastic place to work.  Great people, great environment, and excellent experience.
cons: Like any job, there will be difficult people, but otherwise it was great.

review_title: Interesting and enlightening. HR department lacks common sense in dealing with complaints.
pros: Great benefits, notoriety, and college campus provides a sense of youthfulness for those that enjoy being around young people. Great educational opportunities.
cons: Lacks professinoalism found in the private sector and HR is terrible at evaluating and handling complaints. University lacks the initiative to terminate bad employees.

pros: Lax, plenty of vacation, sick leave. Good health benefits. The work is an amount that can be accomplished without being overwhelmed.
cons: What you start with is all you get... minimal room for growth. Must meet minimum qualifications for positions to even have your application seen.

pros: Flexible hours, I really enjoy collaborating with others as well. I am learning a lot about computer aided manufacturing and manufacturing in general.
cons: Project may be broad. You may not know what the professor actually wants in the project description. I think that the description should be better

review_title: Never work for Housing and Dining.
pros: You can work on homework at the desk.
cons:
Everything in Housing and Dining is a popularity contest. They decide who they like, pick favorites, and everyone else is unimportant. 
They hate change. You want to get a new fridge for the kitchen. The process takes about six months to a year. So basically you will be making the place nicer for the next set of residents.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: Good pay, good advisor, good and competitive colleagues, nice people, nice library, nice campus, can find house near campus, low living cost, high salary, love the campus.
cons: I do not like my job because I do not like my major, okay it is all my fault, I type here is just to fill in this form so as to finish the rate. I love K-state anyway.

pros:
Nice work environment, cubicles up to date and chairs are comfy
It is a State job, it is fairly secure
Friendly people and atmosphere
cons: It is a State job, locked incremental raises if any...at the mercy of the state government which is a separate but related issue.

pros: The Political Science department is more than a group of colleagues but become more of a family.  They are very professional and willing to help.
cons: The only con is the job position structure does not allow for salary or job growth within the position.  That is not a problem with the department of the school but a problem by the state.

review_title: Great place to live and work
pros: K-State faculty care about student success. It's a very rewarding place to work and a wonderful atmosphere surrounds the campus and community. Manhattan is the quintessential college town and the students are very motivated.
cons: Very few. Salaries are not as competitive as some other institutions but the cost of living and quality of life more than make up for this.

pros: The campus is beautiful and mostly well maintained. The student population is friendly as is most of the faculty and staff.
cons: Recently hired a lot of new directors and they are flying by the seat of their pants. It looks like the administration is trying to get rid of the people that have the institutional knowledge and history.

job_title: Student Web Developer in Manhattan, KS
pros: The people, the clean air, the fun campus activities and events. Relatively safe place to live, with little to no traffic.
cons: You have to pay for a parking permit, which can be expensive if on a low income. Also, parking spots are oversold; get to work by 7:45 AM, or you may not have a place to park.

job_title: Office Specialist II in Manhattan, KS
pros: The people are really nice and friendly. Everyone has been very helpful. The benefits are good.
cons: They talk in a lot of acronyms which makes it difficult to catch on at first. Some of the tasks are not as challenging as I'd hoped.

job_title: Division of Continuing Education in Manhattan, KS
pros: The working environment is second to none. Most all employees are welcoming and friendly. Many opportunities exist for personal growth -- take them.
cons: The city of Manhattan, KS can seem a bit small and bland at times. Compensation remains below average for other Big 12 schools.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Manhattan, KS
pros: it is a nice place to live here. there are all kind of people from all over the world. and there is an airport (MHK).
cons:
the airport is a little bit small, only AA is available, no much choice.
winter is a little bit long for me, you need time to get used to it if you are come from  a south worm place

pros: Bright people in science and engineering.
cons: The computer science department is run pretty much by one group. Bright folks, but their stuff is most important, and anything else takes a backseat. That includes master and doctoral students, post-docs, and new professors: if you don't play ball, you don't get far; if you play ball, your career development suffers.

pros: KSU student work is fairly simple and gives great experience. The scheduling is flexible and you will have regular hours.
cons: Full-Time staff can be condescending and sometimes micromanaged. They could use to learn to treat part-time workers as peers in an office as this will help prepare the students for a "real-world" office

review_title: Comfortable, but a great learning experience.
pros: They are very, very flexible with student schedules. I have also made some of my best friends at this job.
cons: I couldn't afford to support myself at tho this job. It only paid minimum wage, and the hours were 8-5, meaning with my student schedule I couldn't pick up more hours.

review_title: Good place to work, but salary isn’t keeping up at this time with other comparable positions.
pros: Great environment. Dedicated professionals work to make a great learning environment for students. I really many aspects of my work.
cons: Salary- little room to advance. Quickly decentralizing services that will impact many aspects of work. Due to state budget and decreasing enrollment, this likely will not improve.

pros: If you like small slow towns, it is a great place to settle.
cons: The pay is terrible.  Faculty rarely get raises.  Our current average pay is between the University of Wyoming and North Dakota State and we didn't get raises this year.

job_title: Human Resources Benefits Administration in Manhattan, KS
pros: Very positive, exciting campus. Treated like family. Communications very current as to work or school activities. Understand the 2025 vision. LOVE the President of the university
cons: Very few Cons. Some buildings are over crowded. It is easier to walk or bike on campus versus driving. Some work areas are understaffed do to budget constraints

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Manhattan, KS
pros:

- Federal holidays

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Manhattan, KS

Friendly people, someone is always around to help. Its a great place for a small town individual to get an education.
Easy to get around.
cons: The graduate programs are not very structured. Also if you are used to a city with lots of things to do in your spare time, you will not find as much to do.

review_title: Great experience by even better people.
pros: Great personal, along with a flexible schedule and decent pay. I enjoy the working environment both at work, and during lunch break at the Union.
cons: Parking is sometimes hard to find, and the parking passes are ridiculously expensive. Other then that, there's not a whole lot to complain about.

job_title: Ticket Sales Representative in Manhattan, KS

cons: The only downside about working here are the slow periods when there aren't any sports going on and the office is slow.

pros: Very accommodating to scheduling and in general set up to be a very learning work environment
cons: Somewhat limited position, and obviously would be no way to further career other than experience in current position.

review_title: Great Community at the College of Architecture

job_title: Physics TA and Student in Manhattan, KS

Good engineering college.

Great football team.
Good sports in general, awesome fan experience.

There are no real cons I can think of.
KSU obviously isn't one of the top schools in the country but can get you really good jobs especially out of engineering.

job_title: Scene Shop Supervisor in Manhattan, KS

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Manhattan, KS

nice people 
my professor was very supportive and encouraging

review_title: Graduate Student Assistant....About What You Would Expect

review_title: I've worked in many departments in Housing and Dining. The only one I kind of liked was working at the Derb.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Manhattan, KS

pros: Flexible hours, great place for a student to work, advancement opportunities, great college jobs available, friendly people and atmosphere
